Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the University of Georgia's Savannah River Ecology Laboratory (SREL), located near Aiken, SC, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2015- 2017. The award will provide a unique training opportunity for training undergraduates in radioecology. Students will engage in field and laboratory studies aimed at describing, understanding and predicting i) the fate of radionuclides in environmental systems; ii) the impact of radionuclides on the environment; and iii) biogeochemical and physiological processes by means of tracer studies. SREL's history of radioecology research in national and international arenas (e.g., Chernobyl and Fukushima) will be leveraged with current analytical capabilities, access to natural and industrial field sites with a variety of contaminant histories, and custodianship of the only chronic low-dose experimental facility in the world. REU students, selected by mentors based on student interest, will gain insight into ethical and responsible research conduct from faculty and scientists at SREL, University of South Carolina Upstate, University of South Carolina Aiken, and University of South Carolina Columbia while pursuing research in ecotoxicology, ecophysiology, environmental restoration, remediation, risk assessment, ecosystem ecology, and radioecology. This multi-university collaboration will allow for recruitment of a diverse group of undergraduate participants, facilitate continued mentorship of participants, and encourage regional partnerships.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities and from regional HBCUs, will be trained in the program each summer. Students will actively learn the process of science and many will present their research at scientific conferences and symposia.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://www.srel.uga.edu/education/ugrad.html, or by contacting the PI (Dr. J Vaun McArthur at mcarthur@srel.uga.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Melissa Pilgrim at mpilgrim@uscupstate.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

The Savannah River Ecology Laboratory (SREL) is a research unit of the University of Georgia located on the Department of Energy?s Savannah River Site near Aiken, SC. SREL served as an REU Site in Radioecology during 2015-2018 (3-year award, with subsequent 1-year supplement). The 10-week summer research program supported a total of 41 undergraduates, each of whom was paired with an established scientist or research group to conduct independent research in radioecology. Research focused on describing, understanding and predicting: i) the fate of radionuclides in environmental systems (artificial and natural); ii) the impact of radionuclides on the environment; and iii) impacts of secondary contaminants of nuclear production on the environment. In addition to their independent research projects, students attended lectures and seminars on radioecology, toured SREL research sites through group field trips, participated in professional development workshops, and interacted with SREL graduate students and scientists and well as visiting researchers. Recruiting efforts targeted students with few research opportunities at their home institutions, including smaller campuses within the University of South Carolina system whose close proximity encourages continued collaboration between students and their mentors following their REU experience.

 

 

Intellectual merit:

This REU site provides the only hands-on training in radioecology opportunity for undergraduates in the world, educating young scientists in the fate and effects of radiological and other contaminants in the environment at a time when nuclear energy production is undergoing a renaissance. The program leverages SREL?s history of radioecology research in national and international arenas (Chernobyl, Fukushima) and provides unique access to natural and industrial field sites with a variety of contaminant histories. Participants conduct multi-disciplinary research projects and present their work at a research symposium that is attended by all SREL researchers and scientists from other organizations also working on the Savannah River Site, who collectively address environmental issues and directly inform management of the site. Through these experiences, students learn the fundamentals of radioecology and basic ecology, gain an appreciation for the diversity of research topics related to radioecology, and are immersed in a research setting in which basic research has clear, direct linkages to environmental management and policy.

 

Broader impacts:

The main broader impact of this REU program is the development of a scientific workforce well-equipped to tackle environmental issues resulting from industrial activities. The students trained by this program will understand the importance of conducting interdisciplinary, collaborative research to address societal needs. In addition, recruitment of students from regional undergraduate-only universities, with limited access to STEM opportunities, led to strengthened collaborations among our institutions. Students return to their home institution with both an oral and poster presentation that encourages them to present their research at other venues, which 56% have done. Participants can also leverage their REU experience by using their research as the basis for honors theses, which also fosters continued interaction between students and mentors. Many of the participants have returned to SREL in future years as graduate students or research technicians, encouraging their retention in STEM fields. Overall, at least 70% of students are still involved in STEM either as undergraduate majors, graduate students, or in the STEM workforce. Finally, the Radioecology REU Site leverages a USDOE supported laboratory, scientists and equipment with NSF support for undergraduate training and hands-on research experience in radioecology, which is not supported by DOE funds.
